sub_topic: Probability of a certain outcome in a sports game
message_1: A basketball player has a free-throw percentage of 85%. If she takes 10 free-throws in a game, what is the probability that she will make exactly 7 of them?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we will use the binomial probability formula:

P(X = k) = C(n, k) * p^k * (1-p)^(n-k)

where:
- P(X = k) is the probability of making exactly k free-throws
- C(n, k) is the number of combinations of n items taken k at a time (also written as nCk or "n choose k")
- n is the total number of free-throws (10 in this case)
- k is the number of successful free-throws (7 in this case)
- p is the probability of making a free-throw (0.85 in this case)
- (1-p) is the probability of missing a free-throw (0.15 in this case)

First, we need to find C(10, 7), which is the number of ways to choose 7 successful free-throws out of 10:

C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * (10-7)!)
C(10, 7) = 10! / (7! * 3!)
C(10, 7) = 3628800 / (5040 * 6)
C(10, 7) = 3628800 / 30240
C(10, 7) = 120

Now, we can plug the values into the binomial probability formula:

P(X = 7) = C(10, 7) * p^7 * (1-p)^(10-7)
P(X = 7) = 120 * (0.85)^7 * (0.15)^3

P(X = 7) ≈ 120 * 0.3203 * 0.003375
P(X = 7) ≈ 129.96 * 0.003375
P(X = 7) ≈ 0.4384

So, the probability that the basketball player will make exactly 7 out of 10 free-throws is approximately 43.84%.
